Videos.longDescription: This video goes over the basics of the Spanish alphabet and pronunciation
Videos.shortDescription: This video goes over the basics of the Spanish alphabet and pronunciation.
Videos.title: Spanish Alphabet & Pronunciation
Videos.description:
In this lesson you learn about the fundamentals of Spanish where you learn the alphabet as well as basic Spanish phrases and sentences. The Spanish alphabet contains 27 letters. It has one more letter than the English alphabet—Ñ. Each letter is pronounced very differently, where each pronunciation is shown in the referenced image.

Spanish shares many familiar words with English: 'I' is 'yo', 'in' is 'en', 'is' is 'es', and 'am' is 'soy'. Other core vocabulary includes 'he' (él), 'she' (ella), and 'Spanish' (español). These words combine similarly to English. For example, 'I am in Spanish' translates word-for-word as 'Yo soy en español'.

However, Spanish uses verb conjugation rules, so just like 'he am' is incorrect in English, 'Él soy' is incorrect in Spanish. Instead, you say 'He is' → 'Él es'. At the beginning stage of learning Spanish, word-for-word translations are often possible, but it’s important to recognize grammatical agreements like conjugation.
trivia: Did you know that Spanish has conjugations just like English?
Did you know that CH, LL, and RR are considered digraphs, not letters, in Spanish?
Did you know that the Spanish alphabet originates from the Latin alphabet?

Videos.longDescription: This video will go over the countries that speak spanish.
Videos.shortDescription: This video will go over the countries that speak spanish.
Videos.title: Spanish Speaking Countries
Videos.description:
In this lesson you will learn about all the countries that speak Spanish in the world. In total, there are 21 countries that have Spanish as their official language. In North America, there are 10 Spanish-speaking countries. Within the continent, 6 of them are in Central America: Guatemala, El Salvador, Nicaragua, Costa Rica, Honduras, and Panama. Three are in the Caribbean: Cuba, the Dominican Republic, and Puerto Rico. The largest of them, Mexico, is located just north of Central America.

In South America, 9 countries have Spanish as an official language: Venezuela, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, Bolivia, Chile, Paraguay, Uruguay, and Argentina.
trivia: Did you know that 595 million people speak Spanish in the entire world?
Did you know that Spanish is the 4th most spoken language in the world?
Did you know that the United States has the second largest population of Spanish speakers in the world?

Videos.longDescription: This video will go over basic spanish conjugation of verbs
Videos.shortDescription: This video will go over basic spanish conjugation of verbs.
Videos.title: Basic Spanish Verb Conjugation
Videos.lessonTitle: Lesson 3: Verb Conjugation - AR, ER, IR
Videos.description:
In this lesson you will learn that there are conjugations in Spanish just like in English. In Spanish, there are three types of verbs that have different endings: AR, ER, and IR verbs. When used in a sentence, the verb endings change depending on the subject. For example, if you want to say 'I eat' in Spanish, you take the verb 'comer' (to eat) and conjugate it as 'como', resulting in 'Yo como.' This lesson focuses only on present tense conjugations.

Some common Spanish verbs are: ser (to be - permanent), estar (to be - temporary), tener (to have), hacer (to do/make), ir (to go), poder (to be able/can), saber (to know - facts), poner (to put), haber (to have - auxiliary/helping verb), querer (to want/love), decir (to say/tell), hablar (to speak), dar (to give), ver (to see), comer (to eat), tomar (to take/drink), vivir (to live), necesitar (to need), quedar (to stay/remain/be left), and venir (to come).

For this lesson, focus on the regular verbs: hablar, comer, tomar, vivir, necesitar, and quedar. These follow standard conjugation patterns and are ideal for learning how to form present-tense sentences.
trivia: Did you know that Spanish has 16 distinct complete verb tenses?
Did you know that most Spanish verbs are conjugated irregularly?
Did you know that Spanish verbs are often used without an explicit subject?

Videos.longDescription: This video will go over food and verbs related to it.
Videos.shortDescription: This video will go over food and verbs related to it.
Videos.title: Spanish Food & Verbs
Videos.lessonTitle: Lesson 4: Food Vocabulary & Regular Verb Use – comer & beber
Videos.description:
In this lesson, you will expand your Spanish skills by diving into one of everyone’s favorite topics: food. You’ll focus on two essential regular verbs: comer (to eat) and beber (to drink), and learn how to conjugate them in the present tense using food-related vocabulary.

For example, just as you learned in the previous lesson, the verb form changes depending on the subject. So, 'You eat hamburgers' becomes 'Tú comes hamburguesas.'

Some key vocabulary words introduced in this lesson include: leche (milk), agua (water), hamburguesa (hamburger), and manzana (apple).

You’ll also learn additional food vocabulary like: pan (bread), arroz (rice), pollo (chicken), carne (meat), pescado (fish), huevo (egg), queso (cheese), plátano (banana), naranja (orange), fresa (strawberry), ensalada (salad), papas/patatas (potatoes), verduras (vegetables), tomate (tomato), cebolla (onion), ajo (garlic), frijoles (beans), sopa (soup), jugo/zumo (juice), refresco (soda), helado (ice cream), torta/pastel (cake), and galleta (cookie).

You’ll use familiar conjugation patterns and combine them with new vocabulary to express real-life situations involving meals and drinks.
trivia: Did you know that ceviche is so important to Peruvian culture that there's a holiday dedicated to it?
Did you know that tamales are traditionally made in large batches during Christmas and other Mexican celebrations?
Did you know that people in Argentina often eat locro, a hearty stew, on May 25th to honor the country’s revolution?

Videos.longDescription: This video will go over things around the house and verbs related
Videos.shortDescription: This video will go over things around the house and verbs related to it.
Videos.title: Spanish House & Verbs
Videos.scrolltext: This video will go over things around the house and verbs related to it.
Videos.lessonTitle: Lesson 5: Around the House – Vocabulary & Regular Verb Practice
Videos.description:
In this lesson, we’ll explore Spanish vocabulary related to the home and practice present-tense conjugation using four regular verbs: lavar (to wash), limpiar (to clean), mirar (to watch), and abrir (to open).

We’ll use common household objects in our sentences, such as puerta (door), platos (plates), películas (movies), and cama (bed). The conjugation process mirrors what you've learned in previous lessons—changing the verb to match the subject and applying it to the correct noun. For example: 'He opens the door' becomes 'Él abre la puerta.'

Additional vocabulary includes items you’re likely to see around the house: mesa (table), silla (chair), sofá (sofa/couch), ventana (window), pared (wall), techo (ceiling/roof), piso (floor), baño (bathroom), cocina (kitchen), refrigerador (refrigerator), microondas (microwave), horno (oven), lavaplatos (dishwasher), fregadero (sink), espejo (mirror), ducha (shower), inodoro (toilet), toalla (towel), televisor (TV), lámpara (lamp), alfombra (carpet/rug), cortina (curtain), cuadro (picture/frame), ropa (clothes), armario (closet), cajón (drawer), escoba (broom), and aspiradora (vacuum cleaner).

By the end of this lesson, you’ll be able to describe actions and objects commonly found in a home using basic Spanish sentence structures.
trivia: Did you know that Spaniards have a famous saying, 'mi casa es tu casa' which means 'my house is your house'? It reflects the warm and welcoming nature of Spanish-speaking cultures.
Did you know that the Spanish word 'casa' comes from the Latin 'căsa,' which originally meant 'hut' or 'cottage'?
Did you know that many Spanish homes feature exterior roller blinds called 'persianas' to keep rooms cool and provide privacy?
